Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris

As the oxymoronic title of this entertaining show suggests, the seven participating artists, all under 40, are interested not in nature but in nature-inspired kitsch. The show is appropriately placed in a public sculpture court -- itself a contradictory mix of the urban and the pastoral, the indoors and the out.

At one end of the court stands a comical fantasyscape by Rob de Mar, a spindly tree with curved steel branches supporting little cartoonish islands -- miniature forests, bucolic parking lots, a swerving country road, a waterfall -- all coated in colored flocking. High on one wall hangs Lisa Ruyter's billboard-size painting of people lounging in the grass near Central Park Lake. Outlined and garishly colored, paint-by-numbers style, it psychedelically updates Seurat's ''Grande Jatte.''

More site-specifically, Peter Gould cleverly redesigned the guard station into a three-dimensional cartoon with a bright green Formica desk top on stacked bricks set off against a small forest of green tree silhouettes. And Jason Middlebrook built into the window sills along Park Avenue a long, fake rock wall with fake flowers planted along its top.

Into an existing flower box, Katrin Asbury placed a miniature red rock diorama inhabited by little hyenalike animals; in another planter, Alyson Shotz installed a grove of weird, plant-machine hybrids: tall, slender stalks made of Q-tips coated in green rubber with wheels instead of roots. And high overhead Rachel Feinstein hung a big, rococo-style papier-mache pitcher from which flowers burst as if from an exploded pinata. All of which reflects a society longing for but deliriously disconnected from the world of nature.
